communications.communication:

title: Domestic Policy Council EO 14201 reports

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any documents (including reports, meeting notes, email and text communications) related to the Assistant to the President for Domestic Policy following the directive in Sec. 4 of President Donald Trump's executive order 14201, known as "Keeping Men Out of Women’s Sports." 

The order calls for the assistant to 1. convening representatives of major athletic organizations and governing bodies, as well as female athletes, to promote policies that are fair and safe, in the best interests of female athletes, and consistent with the requirements of Title IX, as applicable and 2. convening State Attorneys General to identify best practices in defining and enforcing equal opportunities for women to participate in sports and educate them about stories of women and girls who have been harmed by male participation in women’s sports. 

I am requesting all records about and from these conventions, from the Assistant to the President for Domestic Policy and any other party in the Domestic Policy Council. 

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Trans Journalists Association

title: License View Database

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: License View Database
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Until recently, it was possible to download bulk FCC license data directly from the following link: https://data.fcc.gov/download/license-view/fcc-license-view-data-csv-format.zip. However, this link no longer appears to be active, and I have been unable to locate an alternative source for the complete dataset. Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I am requesting a current copy of the License View database in CSV format.

Specifically, I request that the file includes the following columns:

license_id (float),
source_system (varchar),
callsign (varchar),
facility_id (float),
frn (varchar),
lic_name (varchar),
common_name (varchar),
radio_service_code (varchar),

If possible, I respectfully request that the dataset be provided electronically, either as a direct download link or via email.

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Any letter sent by Interim United States Attorney Ed Martin containing the words "I receive requests". 

2. Any communications sent to or from United States Attorney Ed Martin which mention "Wikimedia", "Wikipedia", "Wiki", or *wiki* (i.e., using asterisks as wildcards such that a search would return, e.g., https://wikipedia.org/). 

This request is limited to letters or communications sent to or received by Martin on or after January 20, 2025.

"Communications" means and includes emails, text messages, social media messages, letters, memoranda, calendar entries, chats, or any form of one-to-one or one-to-many communication.

Please note that this request seeks public records wherever they may be found, including on devices or networks owned or operated by private parties. For example, if an employee uses a personal cell phone or social media account to conduct public business, records created, maintained, or held on the phone or account are public records subject to this request.

REQUEST FOR EXPEDITED PROCESSING:

I request that this request be expedited under 28 CFR § 16.5(e)(1)(ii) and (iv) for the following reasons:

1. I certify the following to be true and correct: My organization is primarily engaged in disseminating information. The Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression (FIRE) maintains a news website at https://thefire.org/news, through which its staff members regularly publish news stories and editorial content concerning the activities of governments, government officials, and other persons or organizations of public concern. I am a staff member of FIRE. I frequently write about matters involving the First Amendment and academic freedom, including on FIRE's website. See, e.g., https://www.thefire.org/news-archive?author=303. A substantial component of my duties as a staff member of FIRE is to obtain information through public records requests, including through the Freedom of Information Act, which I or my colleagues then share through FIRE's website and social media channels. I also publish news and other information of public concern via "X" (https://x.com/adamsteinbaugh) and "Bluesky" (https://bsky.app/profile/adamsteinbaugh.bsky.social).

The Department has previously granted FIRE expedited processing in a related request. See Request No. EOUSA-2025-003687 (Apr. 24, 2025).

2. The requested information concerns an actual or alleged government activity, namely an Interim United States Attorney's practice of sending letters seeking "information" for speech protected by the First Amendment. Specifically, Ed Martin has sent letters to (a) Georgetown University Law Center concerning its faculty members' classroom teaching (https://www.ncronline.org/files/2025-03/3.7.24%20Ed%20Martin%20letter%20%20to%20Georgetown%20law.pdf); (b) U.S. Sen. Charles E. Schumer concerning U.S. Supreme Court Justices Brett Kavanaugh and Neil M. Gorsuch (https://www.washingtonpost.com/dc-md-va/2025/02/19/ed-martin-dc-letters-schumer-garcia/); (c) U.S. Rep. Robert Garcia concerning comments made about Elon Musk (https://bsky.app/profile/robertgarcia.bsky.social/post/3lin33orhnk2r); and (d) a medical journal's editor (https://x.com/_Eric_Reinhart/status/1912958244768690407).  This request cocnerns an additional letter Martin sent to Wikimedia Foundation, Inc. (https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ocNyx34Et19sKtlta0bTPPzSPcpi375T/view).

3. The requested information extends beyond the public's right to know about government activity generally and instead has a particular value that would be lost if not processed on an expedited basis. The information pertains to a news story of public interest. That issue has attracted a wide range of news media coverage, including the numerous articles identified below, which are helpful in establishing that there is an urgency to inform the public on this topic.

Examples of recent articles demonstrating the public's ongoing and current interest in this information include articles:

a. https://www.thefp.com/p/trump-prosecutor-threatens-wikipedia
b. https://www.washingtonpost.com/dc-md-va/2025/03/05/dc-us-attorney-ed-martin-georgetown-law-dei/
c. https://thepostmillennial.com/us-atty-ed-martin-demands-georgetown-law-school-answer-for-dei-in-curriculum-hiring-and-programs
d. https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/06/us/politics/ed-martin-us-attorney-washington-trump.html
e. https://thehill.com/homenews/education/5181345-georgetown-law-school-dei-trump/
f. https://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow-show/maddowblog/trump-appointed-prosecutor-gets-much-needed-refresher-first-amendment-rcna195321
g. https://www.rawstory.com/ed-martin-georgetown-clash/
h. https://reason.com/volokh/2025/03/07/may-government-refuse-to-hire-notre-dame-students-because-notre-dame-teaches-and-promotes-anti-abortion-ideology
i. https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/mar/06/ed-martin-us-attorney-dei
j. https://www.newsmax.com/politics/georgetown-dei-william-treanor/2025/03/06/id/1201790/
k. https://www.wusa9.com/article/news/politics/federal-fallout/georgetown-law-school-wont-bow-to-dei-threat-from-dcs-acting-federal-prosecutor-ed-martin-donald-trump-william-treanor/65-22ac5a1d-43a8-492b-92db-1f8c6f70f76c
l. https://www.usatoday.com/story/opinion/columnist/2025/03/07/dei-georgetown-us-attorney-first-amendment/81793644007/
m. https://www.washingtonian.com/2025/03/07/william-treanor-georgetown-law-ed-martin-first-amendment/
n. https://abovethelaw.com/2025/03/georgetown-law-to-ed-martin-f-all-the-way-off/
o. https://www.thecollegefix.com/top-d-c-federal-prosecutor-says-he-doesnt-want-law-students-from-georgetown-because-of-dei/
p. https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2025/03/georgetown-william-treanor-ed-martin-trump-doj-dei.html
q. https://www.washingtonpost.com/dc-md-va/2025/02/19/ed-martin-dc-letters-schumer-garcia/
r. https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/03/us/politics/us-attorney-justice-dept-schumer-inquiry.html
s.  https://www.mediaite.com/politics/maga-u-s-attorney-sends-letter-to-house-democrat-over-criticism-of-elon-musk-who-you-call-a-dick/
t. https://www.rawstory.com/trump-justice-department-2671190340/
u. https://www.yahoo.com/news/acting-dc-us-attorney-ed-150929791.html
v. https://www.techdirt.com/2025/02/21/trumps-dc-us-attorney-launches-project-whirlwind-to-investigate-critics-for-their-speech/

4. This information is relevant to a matter of widespread and exceptional media interest in which there exist possible questions about the government's integrity that affect public confidence. There is widespread and exceptional media interest in this matter, as reflected in the above articles originating from outlets across the ideological spectrum, including the article published by The Free Press concerning Martin's letter to Wikimedia (https://www.thefp.com/p/trump-prosecutor-threatens-wikipedia). This matter raises "possible questions" about government integrity affecting public confidence because the alleged conduct involves a United States Attorney's pressure on educational institutions, academic publications, and elected officials to limit protected speech on matters on public concern. A prominent First Amendment scholar has raised questions about the propriety of Attorney Martin's "inquiry" into Georgetown University Law Center due to its curriculum. Eugene Volokh, "May Government Refuse to Hire Notre Dame Students, Because Notre Dame Teaches and Promotes Anti-Abortion Ideology?" (Volokh Conspiracy, March 7, 2025), https://reason.com/volokh/2025/03/07/may-government-refuse-to-hire-notre-dame-students-because-notre-dame-teaches-and-promotes-anti-abortion-ideology. Further, Attorney Martin's letter to Wikimedia was sent as members of the United States Senate requested disciplinary action against Attorney Martin due to his similar efforts to suppress speech protected by the First Amendment. See https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/06/us/politics/ed-martin-us-attorney-washington-trump.html.

Mr. Martin's letters are of particular interest because they are relevant to his nomination for the office of U.S. Attorney for the District of Columbia. On April 2, 2025, ten members of the United States Senate sent a letter to Sen. Chuck Grassley, Chairman of the U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee, asking him to schedule a hearing to consider Martin’s nomination. (Letter from Sen. Richard J. Durbin, et al., to Sen. Chuck Grassley, Apr. 2, 2025, available at https://s3.documentcloud.org/documents/25878847/ed-martin-hearing-letter-4225-final.pdf.)  At least one prominent commentator has cited Martin’s efforts to chill curriculum at Georgetown (among other efforts to chill speech) as a reason for the Senate to refuse to confirm Martin. (Jack Goldsmith, The Senate and the Edward Martin Nomination, Executive Function (Apr. 3, 2025), https://executivefunctions.substack.com/p/the-senate-and-the-edward-martin.) These concerns, raised by prominent intellectual and political leaders, indicate that Martin's letters raise possible questions about the government's integrity.

REQUEST FOR A FEE WAIVER OR REDUCED FEES:

I request, under 28 CFR § 16.10(k), a waiver or reduction of fees for the following reasons:

1. Disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest because its disclosure would shed light on the operations or activities of the government. The requested information pertains specifically to controversial conduct by an Interim United States Attorney.

2. Disclosure of the requested information would be likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of those operations or activities. Disclosure of the requested information would meaningfully inform the public about the Department's activities and operations.

3. Disclosure of the requested information will contribute to the understanding of a reasonably broad audience of persons interested in the subject, as opposed to the individual understanding of the requester. The requestor is a licensed attorney who practices First Amendment law. As such, the requestor will be able to effectively convey information to the public. Further, the requestor is a representative of the news media. The requestor and his employer, the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression, gather information of potential interest to a segment of the public, turns that information into distinct works (including through its news website, located at https://thefire.org/news), and distributes that information to the public. The information requested here relates to information that is about current events or that would be of current interest to the public. The requestor's past publication record (in addition to FIRE's articles available at https://thefire.org/news) is available at https://www.thefire.org/news-archive?author=303.

4. The requested information is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester. The requestor works for a nonprofit organization and the records are not sought for a commercial purpose.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

communications.communication:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of the Department of Health and Human Services Fiscal Year 2026 (FY26) budget draft, proposed by the Office of Management and Budget. 

Additionally, I request records of all internal communications discussing the budget draft's proposal to cut the 988 Suicide Prevention and Crisis Lifeline’s specialized services for LGBTQ+ youth, dated from Jan. 20, 2025, through the date of search. title: DOE End DEI form submissions

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: DOE End DEI form submissions
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Copies of all submissions to this form: https://enddei.ed.gov/. 

I request a complete waiver of all search and duplication fees. If my request for a waiver is denied, I request that I be considered a member of the news media for fee purposes. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage. In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request.

Under the FOIA Improvement Act of 2016, agencies must adopt a presumption of disclosure, withholding information “only if . . . disclosure would harm an interest protected by an exemption” or “disclosure is prohibited by law.”

The FOIA Improvement Act of 2016 also amended the FOIA as follows (5 USC 552(a)(8)):

(A) An agency shall—
(i) withhold information under this section only if—
(I) the agency reasonably foresees that disclosure would harm an interest protected by an exemption described in subsection (b); or
(II) disclosure is prohibited by law; and
(ii) (I) consider whether partial disclosure of information is possible whenever the agency determines that a full disclosure of a requested record is not possible; and
(II) take reasonable steps necessary to segregate and release nonexempt information. . .

In the event some portions of the requested records are properly exempt from disclosure, please disclose any reasonably segregable non-exempt portions of the requested records. If it is your position that a document contains non-exempt segments, but that those non-exempt segments are so dispersed throughout the document as to make segregation impossible, please state what portion of the document is non-exempt, and how the material is dispersed throughout the document. Claims of nonsegregability must be made with the same degree of detail as required for claims of exemptions in a Vaughn index. If a request is denied in whole, please state specifically that it is not reasonable to segregate portions of the record for release.

Further, “the withholding agency must supply ‘a relatively detailed justification, specifically identifying the reasons why a particular exemption is relevant and correlating those claims with the particular part of a withheld document to which they apply.’”

In addition, I ask that your agency exercise its discretion to release records which may be technically exempt, but where withholding serves no important public interest.

If a portion of the responsive records become available before the entire request is complete, I respectfully request that HHS provide records on a rolling basis.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ileana Garnand

title: 1033 equipment use and policies - agencies with MRAPs (The Dalles Police Department)

communications.subject: Oregon Public Records Law Request: 1033 equipment use and policies - agencies with MRAPs (The Dalles Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Oregon Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Subject of Request:

Records of your agency related to the deployment, use, and acquisition of controlled equipment obtained through the Department of Defense’s 1033 Program, as detailed below.

According to information published by the Defense Logistics Agency (https://www.dla.mil/DispositionServices/Offers/Reutilization/LawEnforcement/PublicInformation/), The Dalles Police Department has received controlled equipment through the 1033 Program, including a Mine-Resistant Ambush Protected (MRAP) vehicle, as reflected in the linked spreadsheet.

I. Requests for Records

Records Request No. 1: All documents constituting, reflecting, relating to, or containing current use policies for each type of 1033 Program controlled equipment, including policies specifying circumstances in which use is authorized or prohibited.

Records Request No. 2: Records listing the dates, locations, suspected offense(s) or rationale for operation, controlled equipment deployed, arrests made, and uses of force associated with each deployment of 1033 Program controlled equipment since May 1, 2019. This includes armored vehicles (such as MRAPs), firearms, and night vision equipment.

Records Request No. 3: All complaints, correspondence, visual or audiovisual materials, and agency responses relating to the use and impact of 1033 Program controlled equipment.

Records Request No. 4: Documents reflecting or relating to the rationale, justification, or criteria for acquisition of 1033 Program controlled equipment prior to its acquisition.

II. Response Time

Under ORS 192.329, agencies must respond to public records requests within five (5) business days to acknowledge receipt of the request, and within an additional ten (10) business days to complete the request or provide a written statement explaining the estimated time required to comply.

If the requested records are available, I ask that they be released on a rolling basis as they are located, rather than waiting for all materials to be compiled.

III. Fees and Public Interest Waiver

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The February 19 executive order  “Ensuring Lawful Governance and Implementing the President’s “Department of Government Efficiency” Deregulatory Initiative” (EO 14219) states: “Within 60 days of the date of this order, agency heads shall provide to the Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs (OIRA) within the Office of Management and Budget a list of all regulations identified by class as listed in subsection (a) of this section.”

https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2025/02/25/2025-03138/ensuring-lawful-governance-and-implementing-the-presidents-department-of-government-efficiency

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records for all relevant names, individuals, agencies and companies. title: Lowell High School reassignment of student newspaper advisor

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Lowell High School reassignment of student newspaper advisor
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. The letter sent by the Journalism Education Association of Northern California concerning the reassignment of Eric Gustafson at Lowell High School.

2. Any communications sent to the Journalism Education Association of Northern California in response to the organization's letter.

3. Any communications sent or received by Jan Bautista, Isaac "Jandro" Alcantar, Chris Lanier, Abby Matthews, or Matt McDonell concerning the reassignment of Eric Gustafson relating to the student newspaper.

4. Any communications sent or received by Jan Bautista, Isaac "Jandro" Alcantar, Chris Lanier, Abby Matthews, or Matt McDonell mentioning any of the following terms: "prior restraint", "prior review", "newspaper", "The Lowell", "adviser", "advisor", "Leonard Law", or "Gustafson"

Requests 3 and 4 are limited to communications sent or received on or after October 1, 2024.

"Communications" means and includes emails, text messages, social media messages, letters, memoranda, calendar entries, chats, or any form of one-to-one or one-to-many communication.

Please note that this request seeks public records wherever they may be found, including on devices or networks owned or operated by private parties. For example, if an employee uses a personal cell phone or social media account to conduct public business, records created, maintained, or held on the phone or account are public records subject to this request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

title: Library Contract Request: Lexis Nexis at Cincinnati State

communications.subject: Ohio Open Records Law Request: Library Contract Request: Lexis Nexis at Cincinnati State
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Ohio Open Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

The most recent contract, governing, base, or master license agreement with LexisNexis, a division of RELX Inc., relating to the licensing of LexisNexis Academic (Nexis Uni);

All related terms and conditions, terms of service, amendments, addenda, appendices, attachments, product terms, MOUs, MOAs, data processing agreements, and/or letters of intent; and

All financial documents or records of financial transactions, exchanges or obligations related to the contractual relations with Lexis Nexis and RELX Inc. for licensing. 

Responsive materials include all contracts, agreements, amendments, appendices, invoices, and any other documents listed above that incorporate language governing terms of use of LexisNexis Academic (Nexis Uni).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

M

MuckRock,

and will respond to you promptly. The time for production of records varies
